children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall control the classification of all buildings and structures as to occupancy and use. Different classifications of occupancy and use represent varying levels of hazard and risk to building occupants and adjacent properties.

children.displayTitle: Section 302 Occupancy Classification and Use Designation

children.body:
Occupancy classification is the formal designation of the primary purpose of the building, structure or portion thereof. Structures shall be classified into one or more of the occupancy groups listed in this section based on the nature of the hazards and risks to building occupants generally associated with the intended purpose of the building or structure. An area, room or space that is intended to be occupied at different times for different purposes shall comply with all applicable requirements associated with such potential multipurpose. Structures containing multiple occupancy groups shall comply with Section 508. Where a structure is proposed for a purpose that is not specifically listed in this section such structure shall be classified in the occupancy it most nearly resembles based on the fire safety and relative hazard. Occupied roofs shall be classified in the group that the occupancy most nearly resembles, according to the fire safety and relative hazard involved, and shall comply with Section 503.1.4.
  1. Assembly (see Section 303): Groups A-1, A-2, A-3, A-4 and A-5.
  2. Business (see Section 304): Group B.
  3. Educational (see Section 305): Group E.
  4. Factory and Industrial (see Section 306): Groups F-1 and F-2.
  5. High Hazard (see Section 307): Groups H-1, H-2, H-3, H-4 and H-5.
  6. Institutional (see Section 308): Groups I-1, I-2, I-3 and I-4.
  7. Mercantile (see Section 309): Group M.
  8. Residential (see Section 310): Groups R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-4.
  9. Storage (see Section 311): Groups S-1 and S-2.
  10. Utility and Miscellaneous (see Section 312): Group U.

diagrams.title: Facilities Not Meeting Educational. Occ.  Def. (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Educational occupancies are defined as those that provide education through the 12th grade, for 6 or more persons, for 4 or more hours per day, or more than 12 hours per week. Similar educating occupancies are not required to meet the educational occupancy requirements. Occupancies such as instructional buildings (corporate environment, college campus, etc.), classrooms with less than a 50 person occupant load, and instructional laboratories are required to meet the fire code requirements for business occupancies. Classrooms with an occupant load of more than 50 persons must meet the assembly occupancy requirements. Laboratories, not used for instruction, must meet the requirements for industrial occupancy.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Accessory Occ.: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Accessory occupancies are part of the mixed occupancy provisions to allow small amounts of spaces that are used by other parts of the same space but not count against them in regards to allowable area calculations. They may be used in combination with separated and non-separated occupancy provisions. For example, an office in a retail establishment, or a small conference room in a large office space.

The two spaces on the left, because they support (and have some sort of spacial connection to the main space), are ancillary; therefore, they can be "Accessory occupancies". Tenant space #2 is separate, does not support the tenant #1 space, nor is it connected. Therefore, it is not ancillary and cannot likely be an accessory occupancy. If a space supports a main space, but is not directly connected, the design professional should make a determination if this is an appropriate accessory occupancy designation.

diagrams.title: Change of Occupancy Group
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where a building or portion thereof undergoes a change in occupancy the building or portion thereof needs to be re-evaluated for compliance with the following:
  • Sprinkler system per Chapter 9
  • Special use / occupancy requirements per 1002
  • Building Elements and Materials per 1011
  • Fire Sprinkler per 1011.2.1
  • Fire Alarm per 10011.2.2
  • Means of Egress per 1011.5
  • Structural per 1006
  • Electrical per 1007
  • Mechanical per 1008
  • Plumbing per 1009
  • Light and ventilation per 1010

diagrams.title: Change of Occupancy Classification
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where a building or portion thereof undergoes a change in occupancy the building or portion thereof needs to be re-evaluated for compliance with the following:
  • Sprinkler system per Chapter 9
  • Special use / occupancy requirements per 1002
  • Building Elements and Materials per 1011
  • Fire Sprinkler per 1011.2.1
  • Fire Alarm per 10011.2.2
  • Means of Egress per 1011.5
  • Structural per 1006
  • Electrical per 1007
  • Mechanical per 1008
  • Plumbing per 1009
  • Light and ventilation per 1010

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Occupancy Classification and Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental use areas on any given level of a building may not occupy more than 10% of the building area of that level. Incidental use areas take on the occupancy classification of the occupancy which the incidental use area is located within.

children.body: Occupancy groups contain subordinate uses having similar hazards and risks to building occupants. Uses include, but are not limited to, those functional designations listed within the occupancy group descriptions in Section 302.1. Certain uses require specific limitations and controls in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 4 and elsewhere in this code.

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - No Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Assembly: No Main Exit or Multiple Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because large crowds in an emergency evacuation situation will tend to exit via the same route used to enter a space the code has special requirements for Main Entrances to assembly spaces with occupant loads that exceed 300. Section 1030 requires that the Main Entry act as a Main Exit. Where the building is an assembly occupancy the code also requires additional clearance on the exit side of Main Exits to ensure that egress is not hindered by occupants that have just exited the space. It requires the main exit to front on a street or an unoccupied space of not less than 10 feet.

diagrams.title: Assembly:  Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because large crowds in an emergency evacuation situation will tend to exit via the same route used to enter a space the code has special requirements for Main Entrances to assembly spaces with occupant loads that exceed 300. Section 1030 requires that the Main Entry act as a Main Exit. Where the building is an assembly occupancy the code also requires additional clearance on the exit side of Main Exits to ensure that egress is not hindered by occupants that have just exited the space. It requires the main exit to front on a street or an unoccupied space of not less than 10 feet.

diagrams.title: Increased Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In some cases an increased occupant load is desired and the code makes an allowance for this provided all of the egress requirements for the increased occupant load are met; such as the number of exits, the egress capacities of the various egress element and the arrangement of the elements provided. The increased occupant load may not exceed 1 occupant per 7 square feet and the building or fire official may require a diagram illustrating how the egress provided meets the requirements of the increased occupant load. The diagram may need to provide the various occupant loads, a seating or equipment layout, exit access aisle locations, and exit locations and capacities. The building or fire official may require the diagram to be posted in the space where the occupant load increase is requested.

diagrams.title: Min. Assembly Aisle Widths
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Minimal aisle width for stepped aisles that serve seating on both sides is 48". Level or ramped aisles serving seating on both sides of the aisle is required to be a minimum of 42". Where an aisle serves seating on only one side, the minimum aisle width can be 36". Where an aisle is divided by a handrail or guard, a minimum of 20" between the rail and seating is required. Exceptions, as shown in this section, apply.

diagrams.title: Air Leakage Vestibule
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Design Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupant loads are determined by the function of the space, not by the occupancy group. Some occupant loads are determined based on gross area, and others are based on net areas, which allows a deduction for certain spaces not usually occupied, such as restrooms serving assembly areas. In this example, the restrooms serving the unconcentrated assembly areas are excluded from the areas for determining occupant loads.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Simultaneous Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Non-Simultaneous  Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

diagrams.title: Assembly Occupancies on Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a roof is utilized as an assembly occupancy, depending on the assembly type, occupant load, the building occupancy, and construction type the floors below the occupied roof may have to be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A-2 occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 100 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 300 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. The code does provide an exception, sprinkler protection of the floors below a group A occupied roof is not required when the building below is both an open parking and of type I or II construction.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Travel from Assembly Seating
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In an assembly occupancy that provides seating whether the seating is fixed or not the maximum travel distance from any seat to a point where two separate paths are available leading to different exits, the common path of travel, may not exceed 30'. In assembly occupancies with an occupant load less than 50 the common path of travel may not exceed 75'. The common path of egress travel shall from seating in a smoke-protected or open-air assembly occupancy may not exceed 50'.

children.body: Assembly Group A occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for the gathering of persons for purposes such as civic, social or religious functions; recreation, food or drink consumption or awaiting transportation.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Assembly, New Construction (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In all new assembly occupancies that have a combined, or aggregate, occupant load of more than 300 the building requires an automatic sprinkler system. If the assembly is a dance hall, discotheques, nightclub, or an audience/spectator accommodation without seating (festival seating) with an occupant load of more than 100, then a fire sprinkler system is required.

children.body: A building or tenant space used for assembly purposes with an occupant load of less than 50 persons shall be classified as a Group B occupancy.

The following rooms and spaces shall not be classified as Assembly occupancies:
  1. A room or space used for assembly purposes with an occupant load of less than 50 persons and accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as a Group B occupancy or as part of that occupancy.
  2. A room or space used for assembly purposes that is less than 750 square feet (70 m2) in area and accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as a Group B occupancy or as part of that occupancy.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Small Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The determination of occupant loads and occupancy groups are independent. Even though the occupancy group for a small assembly area may be a Group B occupancy group, the occupant load factor for "Assembly: Without Tables and Chairs" would be used if the space functions in that way. The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

When adding additional occupant loads, be sure and verify with other code requirements, such as accessibility, exit discharge and also separate bathroom requirements, are not violated. In this instance, increasing the occupant load to larger than what is allowed for a single user restroom could require an additional restroom be added, making the proposed addition problematic. In cases such as this, close working with the Building Official and consideration of the Existing Building code requirements should be considered to determine if an additional bathroom should be added.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements

children.body: A room or space used for assembly purposes that is associated with a Group E occupancy is not considered a separate occupancy.

diagrams.title: Edu. Accessory to Group A
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces that are accessory to and exclusively support the primary E Occupancy are not required to be classified as Assembly occupancy, even if the occupant load exceeds 50. Such spaces still must meet egress requirements of an A occupancy, such as door swing panic hardware, exit signs, emergency lighting, etc. However they would be evaluated concurrent with the E Occupancy for building construction, height/area and fire protection system requirements. Spaces such as multi-purpose rooms, cafeterias and gymnasiums commonly qualify for the exemption. However, it is important to note that if the space is used for purposes other than the primary E Occupancy, such as public gatherings or other community use, it should be classified as A Occupancy, and meet all requirements as such.

children.body: Accessory religious educational rooms and religious auditoriums with occupant loads of less than 100 per room or space are not considered separate occupancies.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Edu. Accessory to Group A
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces that are accessory to and exclusively support the primary E Occupancy are not required to be classified as Assembly occupancy, even if the occupant load exceeds 50. Such spaces still must meet egress requirements of an A occupancy, such as door swing panic hardware, exit signs, emergency lighting, etc. However they would be evaluated concurrent with the E Occupancy for building construction, height/area and fire protection system requirements. Spaces such as multi-purpose rooms, cafeterias and gymnasiums commonly qualify for the exemption. However, it is important to note that if the space is used for purposes other than the primary E Occupancy, such as public gatherings or other community use, it should be classified as A Occupancy, and meet all requirements as such.

children.displayTitle: 303.1.4 Accessory to Places of Religious Worship
children.titleText: Accessory to Places of Religious Worship

children.body:
Group A-1 occupancy includes assembly uses, usually with fixed seating, intended for the production and viewing of the performing arts or motion pictures including, but not limited to:
  • Motion picture theaters
  • Symphony and concert halls
  • Television and radio studios admitting an audience
  • Theaters

diagrams.title: Foyers and Lobbies (Group A-1) Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1029.4 provides the requirements that ensure that lobbies may be exited safely and do not reduce the exiting capacity for the associated A-1 assembly space. It requires that the Foyer or Lobby space does not encroach upon or reduce the capacity of any of the components of the required means of egress for the assembly space. The lobby is required to have a direct connection to all of the main entries and exits or it shall be connected by an unobstructed and straight corridor or path of travel to all main entries and exits.

diagrams.title: Foyers and Lobbies (Group A-1) Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The requirements ensure that lobbies may be exited safely and do not reduce the exiting capacity for the associated A-1 assembly space. It requires that the Foyer or Lobby space does not encroach upon or reduce the capacity of any of the components of the required means of egress for the assembly space. The lobby is required to have a direct connection to all of the main entries and exits or it shall be connected by an unobstructed and straight corridor or path of travel to all main entries and exits.

diagrams.title: Aisle Req. by Occ. Group
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where an aisle or aisle accessway is used as a part of means of egress, it must meet the requirements of this section. The required clearances must be maintained throughout the entirety of the aisle or accessway. For assembly occupancies this section sends the user to Section 1029. For all other occupancy groups the user is sent to section 1005.1, Means of Egress Sizing. This section provides an exception for nonpublic aisles that serve occupant loads of less than 50, for these areas the minimum aisle width can be reduced to 28". Specific to Group M occupancies with merchandise pads, the aisle space between the merchandise pads cannot be less than 30" and the travel distance from these merchandise pads to the path of egress cannot exceed 30'.

Careful attention should also be paid to accessibility requirements of the ADA and state and local accessibility regulations. In such cases where an accessible aisle is required, which includes many work areas, the minimum width is 36", and allows a narrowing of the aisle due to impingements or obstructions to a maximum length of 24" of travel

children.body:
Group A-2 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for food and/or drink consumption including, but not limited to:
  • Banquet halls
  • Casinos (gaming areas)
  • Nightclubs
  • Restaurants, cafeterias and similar dining facilities (including associated commercial kitchens)
  • Taverns and bars

diagrams.title: Aisles with Tables and Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aisle accessways and aisles must be maintained in areas where non-fixed seating exists. Chairs and tables are easy to be moved, rearranged and placed in locations that block aisle accessways and aisles. Even though this is not typically a feature installed during construction, the design of the space and operations after occupancy must continue to consider this code requirement.

diagrams.title: Commercial Kitchens: Occupancy
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Correct classification of a commercial cooking space can affect occupancy separation requirements. Sometimes kitchens are part of the dining experience, and an occupancy separation would be undesirable. However other commercial kitchen spaces can be large enough, or are meant to be a larger production space, like for an entire hospital, that the higher hazard necessitates consideration as something separate from the dining area.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Additions to Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an existing building's size is increased, it must comply with the fire protection requirements of chapter 9 of the building code. An addition is defined as, "An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure." For building additions, the existing building code must be consulted. Additions are specifically addressed in Ch. 11. The user note at the beginning of this chapter states that,"...contains the minimum requirements for an addition that is not separated from the existing building by a fire wall…"

In our example we have a Group A-2 occupancy that is currently 3,000 sq. ft., as is no fire sprinkler protection is required. An addition to the building will increase the total area to 6,000 sq. ft. Based on the fire protection requirements for a Group A-2 in the building code section 903.2.1.2, an A-2 that exceeds 5,000 sq.ft. is required to be equipped throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Alternatively, if a fire sprinkler was not to be installed, the new addition could be separated from the existing by a fire-rated wall. As long as each fire area remains below the requirements for sprinklering, none would be required.

diagrams.title: Indirect Waste (IPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Indirect Waste Pipe: A waste pipe that does not connect directly with the drainage system, but that discharges into the drainage system through an air break or air gap into a trap, fixture, receptor or interceptor.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load: Multiple Function Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category A-2, Restaurant with Commercial Kitchen, Sprinklered
Restaurant space has multiple assembly functions with different ways to calculate occupant loads such as net area, length of seating, and fixed seats. Each individual use area within a common space is required to be accounted for in the calculation.

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is a not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The building code does not explicitly address whether to round occupant loads up at the space or room level. However, section 1004.5 does say "For areas without fixed seating, the occupant load shall be not less than that number determined...". So whether rounding at the before or after the occupant loads are added together, care must be taken to not have an occupant load lower than calculated from the OLF. Rounding down is discouraged as it would most likely violate this requirement. Rounding up at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding. It usually will not make a practical difference unless it is near a threshold which can require an added exit, exit access or additional toilets.

diagrams.title: Food Service Counters (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Food service aisles are required to be accessible in accordance with 227 and 904, specifically 904.5 which requires counters in food service lines to comply. Aisles serving food service lines must comply with 403 and be located on an accessible route, as required by 904.3.

ADA Advisory 277.3. Types of counters that provide different services in the same facility include, but are not limited to, order, pick-up, express, and returns. One continuous counter can be used to provide different types of service. For example, order and pick-up are different services. It would not be acceptable to provide access only to the part of the counter where orders are taken when orders are picked-up at a different location on the same counter. Both the order and pick-up section of the counter must be accessible.

children.body:
Group A-3 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for worship, recreation or amusement and other assembly uses not classified elsewhere in Group A including, but not limited to:
  • Amusement arcades
  • Art galleries
  • Bowling alleys
  • Community halls
  • Courtrooms
  • Dance halls (not including food or drink consumption)
  • Exhibition halls
  • Funeral parlors
  • Gymnasiums (without spectator seating)
  • Indoor swimming pools (without spectator seating)
  • Indoor tennis courts (without spectator seating)
  • Lecture halls
  • Libraries
  • Museums
  • Places of religious worship
  • Pool and billiard parlors
  • Waiting areas in transportation terminals

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Gallery
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently, as specified in section 1004.3. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.5. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.5, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.5.

diagrams.title: Aisles at Tables or Seats: Assembly Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Rooms used for assembly purposes that contains seats, tables, displays, similar fixtures or equipment are also required to maintain the basic concepts of the means of egress. Many of these items may be placed after the Certificate of Occupancy is issued. It's imperative that the placement be part of any design so that the Owner and their representatives will be able to ensure compliance with this section post-occupancy, without the benefit of inspections by the AHJ. Lack of maintained aisles can lead to a hazardous situation, especially in an event that has full occupancy of the space.

diagrams.title: Exits through Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Lobbies, often classified as Group A-3 occupancies or accessory to another Group A occupancy, are frequently gathering or waiting spaces for other assembly areas, or for a catchment area between the public and private areas of a building. The code allows the number of lobby exits only to be based on the occupant load of the lobby, but the width of the exits must be sufficiently sized for the cumulative occupant load. In the example shown, at least three 36" wide doors (assuming 34" actual opening width, with door at 90 degree open angle) would be required to provide the 95.5" min. width.

children.body:
Group A-4 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for viewing of indoor sporting events and activities with spectator seating including, but not limited to:
  • Arenas
  • Skating rinks
  • Swimming pools
  • Tennis courts

diagrams.title: Guardrail Opening Limitations (Ex. 5)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 5
In assembly seating areas, guards required at the end of aisles in accordance with Section 1030.17.4 shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches in diameter up to a height of 26 inches. From a height of 26 inches to 42 inches above the adjacent walking surfaces, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 8 inches in diameter.

children.body:
Group A-5 occupancy includes assembly uses intended for participation in or viewing outdoor activities including, but not limited to:
  • Amusement park structures
  • Bleachers
  • Grandstands
  • Stadiums

diagrams.title: Guardrail Opening Limitations (Ex. 5)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 5
In assembly seating areas, guards required at the end of aisles in accordance with Section 1030.17.4 shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches in diameter up to a height of 26 inches. From a height of 26 inches to 42 inches above the adjacent walking surfaces, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 8 inches in diameter.

diagrams.title: Perimeter Guards at Assembly Seating
diagrams.descriptionHtml: GUARD. A building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level.

diagrams.title: Spaces Under Bleachers (FL)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Protection of storage and other spaces under bleachers prevents unseen danger to the occupants above from an unseen fire below. If bleachers are solid, they may prevent knowledge of a dangerous situation. Conversely, if bleachers are able to allow the passage of smoke, this could also provide a dangerous situation during evacuation to occupants above. Therefore, except for low hazard situations, a one-hour separation (both vertical and horizontal) is required to protect the occupants above.

diagrams.title: Gates as Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In fences and walls that surround a stadium gates may exceed 4' in width. If the gate is a required part of the means of egress it must comply with all of the same requirements applicable to an exit door; panic hardware, kick plates, operating forces, landings, thresholds and spacing requirements, etc. except the gate width is allowed to exceed 4'.

diagrams.title: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Building Code and Existing Building Code sections regarding Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies are to ensure that the occupants of habitable rooms in educational facilities and institutions that provide custodial care such as day cares are capable of exiting any room within the facility. This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

diagrams.title: Facilities Not Meeting Educational. Occ.  Def. (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Educational occupancies are defined as those that provide education through the 12th grade, for 6 or more persons, for 4 or more hours per day, or more than 12 hours per week. Similar educating occupancies are not required to meet the educational occupancy requirements. Occupancies such as instructional buildings (corporate environment, college campus, etc.), classrooms with less than a 50 person occupant load, and instructional laboratories are required to meet the fire code requirements for business occupancies. Classrooms with an occupant load of more than 50 persons must meet the assembly occupancy requirements. Laboratories, not used for instruction, must meet the requirements for industrial occupancy.

diagrams.title: Air Leakage Vestibule
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

diagrams.title: Commercial Kitchens: Occupancy
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Correct classification of a commercial cooking space can affect occupancy separation requirements. Sometimes kitchens are part of the dining experience, and an occupancy separation would be undesirable. However other commercial kitchen spaces can be large enough, or are meant to be a larger production space, like for an entire hospital, that the higher hazard necessitates consideration as something separate from the dining area.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Plumbing Fixture Count: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The calculation shown is based on Section 2902 of the building code using the occupant load factors of Section 1004, assuming half of the occupants are male and half are female. Other states and local jurisdictions may allow other methods which may provide a reduced occupant load, such as certain uses in California such as public schools or state owned buildings (See CPC 422.1, Table 4-1 for example). In addition, other plumbing codes may supersede Chapter 29 and/or have different plumbing fixture ratios than those shown here.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Occ. Loads: Business and Concentrated Business Use
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If more workstations are present than the value of OLF=50 would allow, the Building Official may approve a higher occupant load. If not approved, the maximum number of occupants would be based on an OLF = 50. The Code states Where approved by the building official, the occupant load for concentrated business use areas shall be the actual occupant load but not less than one occupant per 50 square feet.

diagrams.title: Example: Medical Clinic Accessiblity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, all areas must be fully accessible, including multiple spaces of the same type, unless otherwise specified. Areas not required to be fully accessible include certain limited-use or raised spaces that are exempt, employee work areas, and spaces covered by scoping provisions that require only a specified portion of the total number to comply, such as dressing rooms and patient bedrooms.

Advisory 201.1 Scope. These requirements are to be applied to all areas of a facility unless exempted, or where scoping limits the number of multiple elements required to be accessible. For example, not all medical care patient rooms are required to be accessible; those that are not required to be accessible are not required to comply with these requirements. However, common use and public use spaces such as recovery rooms, examination rooms, and cafeterias are not exempt from these requirements and must be accessible.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Design Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupant loads are determined by the function of the space, not by the occupancy group. Some occupant loads are determined based on gross area, and others are based on net areas, which allows a deduction for certain spaces not usually occupied, such as restrooms serving assembly areas. In this example, the restrooms serving the unconcentrated assembly areas are excluded from the areas for determining occupant loads.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

diagrams.title: Partition Live Loads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In building types where partitions are subject to change over time the code requires that the floor structure is able to accommodate future partition changes. To ensure the floor can handle partition loads that change over time, the floor with a specified live load <80 psf are required to to accommodate an additional 15 psf of uniformly distributed live load. This applies to any building in which partitions are subject to frequent changes such as malls, commercial office or retail buildings. In buildings such as hospitals where it may be unclear or the designer is unsure if walls are subject to change, the designer should consult with the Authority Having Jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Occupancy Classification and Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental use areas on any given level of a building may not occupy more than 10% of the building area of that level. Incidental use areas take on the occupancy classification of the occupancy which the incidental use area is located within.

children.body:
Business Group B occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for office, professional or service-type transactions, including storage of records and accounts. Business occupancies shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Airport traffic control towers
  • Ambulatory care facilities
  • Animal hospitals, kennels and pounds
  • Banks
  • Barber and beauty shops
  • Car wash
  • Civic administration
  • Clinic, outpatient
  • Dry cleaning and laundries: pick-up and delivery stations and self-service
  • Educational occupancies for students above the 12th grade
  • Electronic data processing
  • Food processing establishments and commercial kitchens not associated with restaurants, cafeterias and similar dining facilities not more than 2,500 square feet (232 m2) in area.
  • Laboratories: testing and research
  • Motor vehicle showrooms
  • Post offices
  • Print shops
  • Professional services (architects, attorneys, dentists, physicians, engineers, etc.)
  • Radio and television stations
  • Telephone exchanges
  • Training and skill development not in a school or academic program (this shall include, but not be limited to, tutoring centers, martial arts studios, gymnastics and similar uses regardless of the ages served, and where not classified as a Group A occupancy).

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Increased Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In some cases an increased occupant load is desired and the code makes an allowance for this provided all of the egress requirements for the increased occupant load are met; such as the number of exits, the egress capacities of the various egress element and the arrangement of the elements provided. The increased occupant load may not exceed 1 occupant per 7 square feet and the building or fire official may require a diagram illustrating how the egress provided meets the requirements of the increased occupant load. The diagram may need to provide the various occupant loads, a seating or equipment layout, exit access aisle locations, and exit locations and capacities. The building or fire official may require the diagram to be posted in the space where the occupant load increase is requested.

diagrams.title: Commercial Kitchens: Occupancy
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Correct classification of a commercial cooking space can affect occupancy separation requirements. Sometimes kitchens are part of the dining experience, and an occupancy separation would be undesirable. However other commercial kitchen spaces can be large enough, or are meant to be a larger production space, like for an entire hospital, that the higher hazard necessitates consideration as something separate from the dining area.

children.body:
The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:
AMBULATORY CARE FACILITY.
CLINIC, OUTPATIENT.
Public and private colleges and universities shall comply with Section 468.
Florida colleges shall comply with Section 453.

This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Simultaneous Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Non-Simultaneous  Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

diagrams.title: Alterations: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group E occupancies, classroom doors with intruder resistant locking must comply with building code Section 1010.2.8. For occupant loads serving 50 or more occupants in Group E, doors must use panic or fire exit hardware, which allows doors to unlatch with a push in the direction of egress. Fire exit hardware is panic hardware approved for fire-rated doors. In addition, Egress doors serving 50 or more occupants may also be electronically locked in accordance with 1010.2.10.

children.body: Educational Group E occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, by six or more persons at any one time for educational purposes through the 12th grade.

Religious educational rooms and religious auditoriums, which are accessory to places of religious worship in accordance with Section 303.1.4 and have occupant loads of less than 100 per room or space, shall be classified as Group A-3 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Edu. Accessory to Group A
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces that are accessory to and exclusively support the primary E Occupancy are not required to be classified as Assembly occupancy, even if the occupant load exceeds 50. Such spaces still must meet egress requirements of an A occupancy, such as door swing panic hardware, exit signs, emergency lighting, etc. However they would be evaluated concurrent with the E Occupancy for building construction, height/area and fire protection system requirements. Spaces such as multi-purpose rooms, cafeterias and gymnasiums commonly qualify for the exemption. However, it is important to note that if the space is used for purposes other than the primary E Occupancy, such as public gatherings or other community use, it should be classified as A Occupancy, and meet all requirements as such.

children.displayTitle: 305.1.1 Accessory to Places of Religious Worship
children.titleText: Accessory to Places of Religious Worship

children.body: This group includes buildings and structures or portions thereof occupied by more than five children older than 21/2 years of age who receive educational, supervision or personal care services for fewer than 24 hours per day.

diagrams.title: Child Care as Group E
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Day cares are typically classified as Group I-4 occupancies. However, they may be classified as a Group E when the building serves a total occupant load of 6-100 persons, under the age of 2-1/2 years, and each room has an exit directly to the outside at the level of exit discharge.

children.body: Rooms and spaces within places of religious worship providing such day care during religious functions shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.
A facility having five or fewer children receiving such day care shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.

A facility such as the above within a dwelling unit and having five or fewer children receiving such day care shall be classified as a Group R-3 occupancy or shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential.
children.displayTitle: 305.2.3 Five or Fewer Children in a Dwelling Unit
children.titleText: Five or Fewer Children in a Dwelling Unit

children.body: Public and private educational occupancies shall comply with Section 468.
Public education occupancies shall comply with Section 453.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

diagrams.title: Egress Through Intervening Spaces: # 2 & 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where it is necessary to access an exit through another space, certain provision must be in place for this to be allowed. Otherwise, access through an intervening space to an exit is prohibited. This section outlines those areas where accessing through a space to an exit is permissible.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Exterior Envelope: Roof - Metal Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

children.body: Factory Industrial Group F occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for assembling, disassembling, fabricating, finishing, manufacturing, packaging, repair or processing operations that are not classified as a Group H hazardous or Group S storage occupancy.

diagrams.title: Guardrail Openings - Exceptions 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 3
At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.
Section 1015.4 Exception 4
In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.

Factory industrial uses that are not classified as Factory Industrial F-2 Low Hazard shall be classified as F-1 Moderate Hazard and shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

children.body: Aircraft manufacturing facilities shall comply with Section 412.7.

Factory industrial uses that involve the fabrication or manufacturing of noncombustible materials that during finishing, packing or processing do not involve a significant fire hazard shall be classified as F-2 occupancies and shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Beverages: up to and including 16-percent alcohol content
  • Brick and masonry
  • Ceramic products
  • Foundries
  • Glass products
  • Gypsum
  • Ice
  • Metal products (fabrication and assembly)

diagrams.title: Guardrail Openings - Exceptions 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 3
At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.
Section 1015.4 Exception 4
In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.

diagrams.title: Egress Width: High Hazard (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The building code requires the width be based on "occupants served". The Life Safety Code and NFPA 1 Fire Code allows the capacity to be calculated based on an occupant load served by the corridor divided by the number of exits the corridor is joined to. However, the width is not allowed to be less than the required capacity of the exit to which it leads.

diagrams.title: Hazmat Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
HazMat MAQ (Section 304.4 → 414.2 → 307.1) - To determine fire protection, construction, and other requirements where hazardous materials are used or stored, the maximum allowable quantity (MAQ) must be determined. To do this the material type, class, state, and use must be known. The quantity will then determine what class of Group H the facility will be considered as. For Group M or Group S occupancies the MAQ differs. Once the MAQ and occupancy group has been determined the construction requirements of WBC 414.2 and the fire protection requirements of WFC Chapter 9 and the specific chapter based on the material, can be established.

When we put these steps together, here is how the process should work:
  1. As the owner of "Widget Business Solutions", I find that there is a need for organic peroxides on site. I start by going to the table in Table 307.1(1) of the building code. This table outlines the MAQ per control area.
  2. In the "Material" column I find 'organic peroxides'. I see that there are different allowances based on class. Further, research into my product reveals that this is a Class III organic peroxide (these burn rapidly and present a moderate reactivity hazard).
  3. Next I need to determine in what state the material will be in. Per the table, the only options available are Solid or Liquid. The material will be utilized in its solid form. It will only be stored, not used (in a closed or open system). Under the column labeled "Storage" and "solid pounds" I see that I can house 125 cubic feet of Class III organic peroxides per single control area. This would classify the occupancy as a Group H-2. If the storage amount was to exceed 125 cubic feet (where permitted), then the occupancy would change to Group H-3.

diagrams.title: Egress Through Intervening Spaces: # 2 & 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where it is necessary to access an exit through another space, certain provision must be in place for this to be allowed. Otherwise, access through an intervening space to an exit is prohibited. This section outlines those areas where accessing through a space to an exit is permissible.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Exception: Group H
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Rooms classified in the Occupancy Groups of H-2 and H-3 contain hazardous materials presenting concern for deflagration, accelerated burning, increased rate of combustion, or other physical hazards. In order to minimize impact of a fire event to the building, and improve suppression/rescue personnel access to these occupancies, the code requires 25% of the occupancy perimeter walls/barriers to be located on the exterior wall. The code allows exceptions to the 25% requirement for the following conditions:
  1. Liquid storage rooms up to 1,000 sf that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code and NFPA 30.
  2. Liquid use, dispensing and mixing rooms up to 500 sf that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code and NFPA 30.
  3. Paint Spray Booths that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code.

It is important to note that the Liquid Storage Room, the Dispensing/Mixing Room and the Paint Spray Booth each have separate requirements specified by both the building and fire codes (e.g. size, construction, location, spill control, secondary containment, operational controls, etc.). In order to qualify for one of the three exceptions the area under consideration must meet all building and fire code requirements for the area.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.
Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Fire Separation Distance: Group H
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The H-1, H-2 and H-3 Occupancies are reserved for buildings having hazardous materials quantities that increase the risk of explosion and/or high intensity fires. Minimum fire separation distances are established to mitigate the impact a fire event will have on adjacent buildings. Fire Separation Distance is measured between the Lot Line and outside face of wall enclosing the H Occupancy. Additional separation may be specified by the Fire Code and referenced standards to address material specific hazard of product used or stored.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Incompatible Materials and Common Shafts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
To avoid chemical reactivity within the exhaust shafts, separated or diluted exhaust systems are required to remove hazardous exhaust streams from the building. The requirement applies to all hazardous exhaust systems, like dip-tanks, spray coating, combustible dust, fume hoods or other operations producing hazardous exhaust streams.

The Fire Code defines incompatible materials as: Materials that, when mixed, have the potential to react in a manner which generates heat, fumes, gases or byproducts which are hazardous to life or property.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Incompatible Materials and Common Shafts - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
To avoid chemical reactivity within the exhaust shafts, separated or diluted exhaust systems are required to remove hazardous exhaust streams from the building. The requirement applies to all hazardous exhaust systems, like dip-tanks, spray coating, combustible dust, fume hoods or other operations producing hazardous exhaust streams.

The Fire Code defines incompatible materials as: Materials that, when mixed, have the potential to react in a manner which generates heat, fumes, gases or byproducts which are hazardous to life or property.

The exception to 509.4 applies only to "laboratory exhaust systems." Per Section 509.1, a laboratory shall be defined as a facility where the use of chemicals is related to testing, analysis, teaching, research or developmental activities. Chemicals are used tor synthesized that laboratory research activities generally produce lower concentration exhaust streams of an intermittent nature, whereas production facilities are more prone to exhaust streams that present a continuous hazard.

children.body: High-hazard Group H occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, that involves the manufacturing, processing, generation or storage of materials that constitute a physical or health hazard in quantities in excess of those allowed in control areas complying with Section 414, based on the maximum allowable quantity limits for control areas set forth in Tables 307.1(1) and 307.1(2). Hazardous occupancies are classified in Groups H-1, H-2, H-3, H-4 and H-5 and shall be in accordance with this section, the requirements of Section 415 and the Florida Fire Prevention Code. Hazardous materials stored, or used on top of roofs or canopies, shall be classified as outdoor storage or use and shall comply with the Florida Fire Prevention Code.

An occupancy that stores, uses or handles hazardous materials as described in one or more of the following items shall not be classified as Group H, but shall be classified as the occupancy that it most nearly resembles.
  1. Buildings and structures occupied for the application of flammable finishes, provided that such buildings or areas conform to the requirements of Section 416 and the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  2. Wholesale and retail sales and storage of flammable and combustible liquids in mercantile occupancies conforming to the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  3. Closed piping system containing flammable or combustible liquids or gases utilized for the operation of machinery or equipment.
  4. Cleaning establishments that utilize combustible liquid solvents having a flash point of 140°F (60°C) or higher in closed systems employing equipment listed by an approved testing agency, provided that this occupancy is separated from all other areas of the building by 1-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or 1-hour horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.
  5. Cleaning establishments that utilize a liquid solvent having a flash point at or above 200°F (93°C).
  6. Liquor stores and distributors without bulk storage.
  7. Refrigeration systems.
  8. The storage or utilization of materials for agricultural purposes on the premises.
  9. Stationary storage battery systems installed in accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  10. Corrosive personal or household products in their original packaging used in retail display.
  11. Commonly used corrosive building materials.
  12. Buildings and structures occupied for aerosol product storage shall be classified as Group S-1, provided that such buildings conform to the requirements of the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  13. Display and storage of nonflammable solid and nonflammable or noncombustible liquid hazardous materials in quantities not exceeding the maximum allowable quantity per control area in Group M or S occupancies complying with Section 414.2.5.
  14. The storage of black powder, smokeless propellant and small arms primers in Groups M and R-3 and special industrial explosive devices in Groups B, F, M and S, provided such storage conforms to the quantity limits and requirements prescribed in the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  15. Mercantile occupancies offering for retail sale sparklers, novelties and trick noisemakers as defined at Section 791.01, Florida Statutes, and that are not defined as fireworks by Chapter 791, Florida Statutes. Storage of sparklers and other novelties or trick noisemakers as defined in Chapter 791, Florida Statutes, within mercantile occupancies shall be in accordance with Section 791.055, Florida Statutes.
  16. Stationary fuel cell power systems installed in accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  17. Capacitor energy storage systems in accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
Hazardous materials in any quantity shall conform to the requirements of this code, including Section 414, and the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
