Buildings and structures containing materials that pose a detonation hazard shall be classified as Group H-1. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Detonable pyrophoric materials
  • Explosives:
    • Division 1.1
    • Division 1.2
    • Division 1.3
    • Division 1.4
    • Division 1.5
    • Division 1.6
  • Organic peroxides, unclassified detonable
  • Oxidizers, Class 4
  • Unstable (reactive) materials, Class 3 detonable and Class 4

The following occupancies containing explosive materials shall be classified as follows:
  1. Division 1.3 explosive materials that are used and maintained in a form where either confinement or configuration will not elevate the hazard from a mass fire to mass explosion hazard shall be allowed in H-2 occupancies.
  2. Articles, including articles packaged for shipment, that are not regulated as a Division 1.4 explosive under Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives regulations, or unpackaged articles used in process operations that do not propagate a detonation or deflagration between articles shall be allowed in H-3 occupancies.
children.displayTitle: [F]  307.3.1 Occupancies Containing Explosives Not Classified as H-1
children.titleText: Occupancies Containing Explosives Not Classified as H-1

children.body:
Buildings and structures containing materials that pose a deflagration hazard or a hazard from accelerated burning shall be classified as Group H-2. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Class I, II or IIIA flammable or combustible liquids that are used or stored in normally open containers or systems, or in closed containers or systems pressurized at more than 15 pounds per square inch gauge (103.4 kPa).
  • Combustible dusts where manufactured, generated or used in such a manner that the concentration and conditions create a fire or explosion hazard based on information prepared in accordance with Section 414.1.3.
  • Cryogenic fluids, flammable.
  • Flammable gases.
  • Organic peroxides, Class I.
  • Oxidizers, Class 3, that are used or stored in normally open containers or systems, or in closed containers or systems pressurized at more than 15 pounds per square inch gauge (103 kPa).
  • Pyrophoric liquids, solids and gases, nondetonable.
  • Unstable (reactive) materials, Class 3, nondetonable.
  • Water-reactive materials, Class 3.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.body:
Buildings and structures containing materials that readily support combustion or that pose a physical hazard shall be classified as Group H-3. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Class I, II or IIIA flammable or combustible liquids that are used or stored in normally closed containers or systems pressurized at 15 pounds per square inch gauge (103.4 kPa) or less.
  • Combustible fibers, other than densely packed baled cotton, where manufactured, generated or used in such a manner that the concentration and conditions create a fire or explosion hazard based on information prepared in accordance with Section 414.1.3.
  • Consumer fireworks, 1.4G (Class C, Common)
  • Cryogenic fluids, oxidizing
  • Flammable solids
  • Organic peroxides, Class II and III
  • Oxidizers, Class 2
  • Oxidizers, Class 3, that are used or stored in normally closed containers or systems pressurized at 15 pounds per square inch gauge (103 kPa) or less
  • Oxidizing gases
  • Unstable (reactive) materials, Class 2
  • Water-reactive materials, Class 2

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.body:
Buildings and structures containing materials that are health hazards shall be classified as Group H-4. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Corrosives
  • Highly toxic materials
  • Toxic materials

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.body: Semiconductor fabrication facilities and comparable research and development areas in which hazardous production materials (HPM) are used and the aggregate quantity of materials is in excess of those listed in Tables 307.1(1) and 307.1(2) shall be classified as Group H-5. Such facilities and areas shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Section 415.11.

Buildings and structures containing a material or materials representing hazards that are classified in one or more of Groups H-1, H-2, H-3 and H-4 shall conform to the code requirements for each of the occupancies so classified.

diagrams.title: Group I-4 Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1006.2.1 (2021 and 2024) outlines how the code considers the varying evacuation needs of different occupancies. It modifies the criteria for requiring two exits based on three factors: the occupancy group, the occupant load, and the common path of egress travel. For instance, an I-4 daycare occupancy has a low threshold, requiring more than 10 occupants for two exits, compared to a B office occupancy, which requires more than 49 occupants. This distinction acknowledges that occupants in a B office can evacuate quickly and independently, while daycare occupants may need assistance and more time, necessitating more accessible egress options.

diagrams.title: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Building Code and Existing Building Code sections regarding Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies are to ensure that the occupants of habitable rooms in educational facilities and institutions that provide custodial care such as day cares are capable of exiting any room within the facility. This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

diagrams.title: Width of Doors in I-2 with Stretchers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1010.1.1 addresses the minimum egress door size where the movement of beds or stretchers is required in an I-2 Occupancy. The minimum required clear opening height is 80 inches and the minimum clear width is 41-1/2 inches. When a door opening contains two door leaves, one leaf is required to provide the minimum clear width.

Doors to specialized areas of hospitals may be required to be wider by the locally adopted standards for hospitals. For example, the Facilities Guidelines Institute standards (2022) requires door openings for patient rooms and diagnostic and treatment areas such as X-ray, surgery, or physical therapy, to be 44-1/2" wide.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group I - Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Institutional, Group I, occupancies are those in which people receive care. These include assisted living facilities, hospitals, day cares, correctional and detention centers. Automatic fire sprinklers are required to be installed within these facilities, with the following exceptions: In Condition 1 facilities, where people receiving care are capable of self preservation, an NFPA 13R sprinkler system is permitted to be installed. Sprinklers are not required in daycares, I-4 occupancies, where each room has an exterior door, and the space is located on the level of exit discharge. However, if the I-4 occupancy is located above or below the level of exit discharge, then sprinklers are required to be installed throughout the floor and all floors to and below the level of exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

children.body: Institutional Group I occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, in which care or supervision is provided to persons who are or are not capable of self-preservation without physical assistance or in which persons are detained for penal or correctional purposes or in which the liberty of the occupants is restricted. Institutional occupancies shall be classified as Group I-1, I-2, I-3 or I-4.

The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:
24-HOUR BASIS.
CUSTODIAL CARE.
DETOXIFICATION FACILITIES.
FOSTER CARE FACILITIES.
HOSPITALS AND PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS.
INCAPABLE OF SELF-PRESERVATION.
MEDICAL CARE.
NURSING HOMES.

Institutional Group I-1 occupancy shall include buildings, structures or portions thereof for more than 16 persons, excluding staff, who reside on a 24-hour basis in a supervised environment and receive custodial care. Buildings of Group I-1 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 308.3.1 or 308.3.2. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Alcohol and drug centers
  • Assisted living facilities
  • Congregate care facilities
  • Group homes
  • Halfway houses
  • Residential board and care facilities
  • Social rehabilitation facilities

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Dwelling and Sleeping Units
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

children.body: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which all persons receiving custodial care who, without any assistance, are capable of responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which there are any persons receiving custodial care who require limited verbal or physical assistance while responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.
A facility housing not fewer than six and not more than 16 persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as Group R-4.
children.displayTitle: 308.3.3 Six to 16 Persons Receiving Custodial Care
children.titleText: Six to 16 Persons Receiving Custodial Care

children.body: A facility with five or fewer persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as Group R-3 or shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential provided an automatic sprinkler system is installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 or Section P2904 of the Florida Building Code, Residential.
children.displayTitle: 308.3.4 Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Custodial Care
children.titleText: Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Custodial Care

children.body:
Institutional Group I-2 occupancy shall include buildings and structures used for medical care on a 24-hour basis for more than five persons who are incapable of self-preservation. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Foster care facilities
  • Detoxification facilities
  • Hospitals
  • Nursing homes
  • Psychiatric hospitals

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Admissions Area Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call out the minimum programmatic requirements for the Admissions Area. An admissions area is required to contain a waiting area for both patients and persons accompanying the patient. A work counter is required for the admissions staff. Space for wheelchair storage that is not within the required path of egress travel is also required.

diagrams.title: Wheelchair Storage and Parking (Hospital)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code ensures that the disabled have reasonable access to and places to store wheelchairs that do not hinder egress. Wheelchair storage in facilities that provide wheelchairs is required to be out of the required means of egress and directly accessible to the entrance for at least one wheelchair. Where patients will be required to transfer from a wheelchair a parking area for at least one wheelchair must be provided that is both in a non-public area and out of any required egress width or required clearances.

diagrams.title: NICU Sound Ratings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order to ensure that neonatal intensive care unit's (NICU) environments are sufficiently quiet for the new born patients, the code calls for minimum sound transmissions coefficients (STC) for the various walls, floors and ceilings that separate NICU's from other functions within the hospital. The required STC separation rating is called out in table A2.2-a, varies from 40 to 65 and is dependent on the adjacent spaces use/function.

diagrams.title: General Rm. Type Reqs. - Operating Rm.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

diagrams.title: General Rm. Type Reqs. - Procedure Rm.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 3 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 2 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 1 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Width of Doors in I-2 with Stretchers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1010.1.1 addresses the minimum egress door size where the movement of beds or stretchers is required in an I-2 Occupancy. The minimum required clear opening height is 80 inches and the minimum clear width is 41-1/2 inches. When a door opening contains two door leaves, one leaf is required to provide the minimum clear width.

Doors to specialized areas of hospitals may be required to be wider by the locally adopted standards for hospitals. For example, the Facilities Guidelines Institute standards (2022) requires door openings for patient rooms and diagnostic and treatment areas such as X-ray, surgery, or physical therapy, to be 44-1/2" wide.

diagrams.title: Grab Bars (Hospital)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because patients will be counting on grab bars being able to support them, the code defines the minimum loading that a grab bar must be able to resist as a concentrated load of 250 pounds. The load may be applied at any point and in any direction along the grab bar. Because some patients are individuals of size the code calls for grab bars serving them to be able to resist a concentrated load of 800 pounds applied at any point and in any direction along the length of the grab bar. To ensure maximum safety the ends of grab bars need to be designed to prevent the snagging of clothing, typically achieved by returning the grab bar end to a wall or floor. The hospital guideline also advises that the finish should contrast the adjacent wall finish and that the bar should provide for a slip resistant gripping surface.

diagrams.title: Hospital Elevators: Dimension and Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because patient occupied beds and attendants need to be transported by the elevators, hospital elevator car clear floor space and door size is defined in the code. The hospital code calls for the clear floor of the car to be 5'-8" minimum wide by 9' minimum deep. The hospital code calls for elevator car doors to have clear opening 48" minimum wide by 84" minimum tall. The car and doorway dimensions are a minimum guide, a larger clear floor space and door opening may be needed to address special facility needs, such as and ICU where multiple attendants and equipment may also need to be transported with the patient. The hospital code allows for elevators provided beyond the minimum needed for patient transport that are for visitor or material handling to be smaller.

diagrams.title: Patient Room Size and Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure adequate room is provided in patient rooms the code defines a minimum clear area and minimum clearances required from the bed to a wall or fixed obstruction. For Single-patient rooms the minimum clear area is 120 sf and the minimum clearance to the side or foot of the bed to a wall or fixed obstruction is 3'. For multiple patient rooms the minimum clear area is 100 sf per bed, 3' clear to the sides of each bed and 4' clear at the foot of each bed to a wall or fixed obstruction. The additional clearance at the foot of the bed called for in multiple-patient rooms is to allow for the passage of beds and equipment. In the event clinical services are to be provided in the room, the room may be required to exceed the minimum room requirements.

diagrams.title: Hand Washing Stations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order to minimize the spread of harmful germs the code requires handwashing stations. The locations and number of required stations are defined in sections 2.1-2.2.5 and 2.1-2.8.7.3. Handwashing stations need to include a sink and faucet that complies with Section 2.1-8.4.3.2. The sink may be wall mounted or in a countertop. If in a countertop the top may be made of porcelain, stainless steel, solid-surface materials, or impervious plastic laminate assembly. If the countertop material such as plastic laminate that requires a substrate, marine-grade plywood (or an equivalent material) with an impervious seal is required. If the sink is located in a cabinet, the cabinet must not allow for storage beneath the sink. Provisions for hand drying need to be provided. Touchless enclosed towel dispensers and touch free hot-air dryers. If a towel dispenser is provided it must be within arm's reach of the sink. A liquid or foam soap dispenser is required. Mirrors over handwashing stations sinks are not allowed at stations in the following locations food preparation areas, nurseries, clean and sterile supply areas, areas where asepsis control would be lessened by hair combing or scrub stations.

diagrams.title: Hospital Reception Areas or Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because there will likely be a disproportionate number of disabled people served by a hospital in comparison to other businesses, the hospital guidelines define what needs to be provided and accessed from within hospital lobbies and reception areas. Within the lobby the following need to be provided:
  • Access to information (typically a reception desk with an attendant).
  • A public waiting area.
  • Public toilet room(s).
  • Access to drinking water.
  • Access to public communications services (phone and internet where available).

diagrams.title: Glazing in Hospital Renovations (FGI)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Wire glass in itself is not considered safety glazing. Beginning with the 2006 edition of building codes, traditional wired glass, which did not conform to safety glazing requirements, was no longer exempt from safety glazing standards when used in any hazardous location for all new construction. If wire glass is used, be sure that it also meets the safety glazing requirements of Building Code Section 2406 as well.

diagrams.title: Hospital Elevators: Number required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that adequate vertical transportation of patient beds is provided in hospitals the code defines the minimum number of "hospital-type" elevators that must be provided. Since the Hospital will be relying on the elevators to move patients if a hospital-type elevator is needed at least 2 will be required to ensure safe continued operation of the hospital in the event of an elevator breakdown. The number of required hospital-type elevators is based on the bed count and the beds' location relative to the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided. When 1 to 59 beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When 60 to 200 patient beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When 201 to 350 patient beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When over 350 patient beds are provided a vertical transportation study based on the plans need to be conducted to determine the number of hospital-type elevators that are required.

diagrams.title: Window Requirements in Patient Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the natural daylight and its cycle are important for the psychological well-being of patients the code requires windows in patient rooms. The code defines the minimum window size based on the required clear floor area for the room, which is defined elsewhere in the code. The window must be sized to provide a minimum net glazed area of 8% of the required clear floor area for the room. If the window provided is operable, its operation needs to be limited such that a 4" sphere cannot pass through the opening to prevent accidental falls from the window. In new construction the window sill height may not exceed 36" above the floor. In renovation work where meeting the standards is impractical or impossible the jurisdiction having authority may grant approval to deviate from the requirements noted above.

diagrams.title: Noise Control (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that patients' healing is not disturbed by excessive noise, the hospital guideline has noise criteria that applies to patient areas. To protect the patients from being disturbed by impact noises recreation, exercise, equipment and similar spaces that generate impact noises are not allowed to be directly over patient bed areas, deliver or operating suites unless special noise reduction provisions are provided. To ensure that patient areas are sufficiently quiet the FGI provides minimum STC (sound transmission class) criteria in table 1.2-6 for patient area ceilings, floors and walls.

diagrams.title: Handrails at Hospital Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call for handrails on both sides of corridors used by patients. Rails are require to be continuous with exceptions being made for doors, nurses stations, alcoves, fire extinguisher cabinets and where features are less than 24" apart (2022). Railing ends are required to return wall or floor. The gripping surface is required to be smooth and free of sharp or abrasive conditions, with 1/8"min. radius. Edges and corners are required to be eased. The finish of the railing must contrast with the wall surface finish by a minimum of 30% and be able to withstand cleaning and disinfection.

diagrams.title: Sprinkler Reqs.  - Hospital Clothes Closets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the clothes closet in a patient sleeping room has an area less than 6' and the distance from sprinkler in the room to the projected backwall of the closet does not exceed the distance of the maximum sprinkler spacing distance from a wall (9.5.3.2 2019 or 8.5.3.2 2016), sprinklers may be omitted.

diagrams.title: Distance of Travel within Group I-2 Sleeping Room
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum exit access travel distance of 50' is allowed in a Group I-2 occupancy sleeping room that is not located in a care suite. The travel distance is measured from any point within the sleeping room to the exit access door of the sleeping room.

diagrams.title: Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

diagrams.title: Gift Shops in I-2 Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies no separation is required between a corridor and a giftshop and its associated storage provided the giftshop is less than 500 sf including storage and the space is constructed as would be required for a corridor.

diagrams.title: Corridor doors in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In a group I-2 occupancy, doors in corridor walls not required to provide fire separation from incidental uses, vertical openings (shafts), or exits are not required to have a fire protection rating or to have self/automatic-closing devices. They must, however, provide an effective smoke barrier and be equipped with positive latching lockset (roller latches not permitted). Where the corridor wall is required to be rated the door openings are required to be protected in accordance with Table 716.1(2).

diagrams.title: Group I-2: Direct Access to Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable rooms in I-2 occupancies such as patient or exam rooms are required to exit via an exit access door directly to a corridor. The code provides for two exceptions to this rule. If the room has an exit door opening directly to the outside at ground level an exit access door leading directly to a corridor is not required. If the room is part of a suite in compliance with section 407.4.4 an exit access door leading directly to a corridor is not required.

children.body: Buildings of Group I-2 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 308.4.1.1 or 308.4.1.2.

This occupancy condition shall include facilities that provide nursing and medical care but do not provide emergency care, surgery, obstetrics or in-patient stabilization units for psychiatric or detoxification, including but not limited to nursing homes and foster care facilities.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

diagrams.title: Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

children.body: This occupancy condition shall include facilities that provide nursing and medical care and could provide emergency care, surgery, obstetrics or in-patient stabilization units for psychiatric or detoxification, including but not limited to hospitals.

diagrams.title: Doors: Swing & Hardware (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, Except for doors serving non-habitable spaces, doors may not swing into corridors unless provided with an alcove that is deep enough to contain the door swing. Latching lever or push/pull type strike side hardware is required on doors except for some operating room conditions. Operating rooms in a designated suite that do not open to an egress corridor are not required to have latching hardware and may be self-closing with push/pull plates.

diagrams.title: Doors: Types & Openings (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Hospital Guidelines allow for two different types of doors, swinging or sliding doors. Where sliding doors are provided they may be manual or automatic providing emergency exiting requirements are not compromised and there are no floor tracks. Emergency breakaway sliding doors prior to breakaway may restrict the minimum corridor width. The minimum door opening size is 44-1/2" wide by 83-1/4" tall for doors to patient rooms and diagnostic and treatment areas. When a swinging door for personnel is provided in addition to a sliding door the swinging door clear width may be reduced to 32".

diagrams.title: Doors: Patient Bathing / Toilet Facilities (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, because patient bathroom doors need to enable rescue access without hitting the occupant when opening the door, configurations allowed are as follows: a single out swinging door, two separate doors, a door with emergency rescue hardware, or a non-pocket sliding door. Visual privacy to toilet and bathing rooms that open to public areas or corridors also needs to be provided.

diagrams.title: Doors and Door Hardware in Behavioral / Mental Health Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In Behavioral and Mental Health Hospitals, all doors and doorway openings in new construction that will be utilized by patients must meet the following minimum requirements:
  • 32" clear opening width from the door face to the strike stop with the door open at 90 degrees.
  • Hardware:
    General: all hardware shall be mounted with tamper-resistant fasteners.
    Closer: if provided shall be mortised type or surface mounted on the public side of the door.
    Hinges:
    • Shall be designed to minimize points for hanging.
    • Shall be consistent with the level of care required for the patients

    Handles: shall be ligature-resistant (without points where a cord, rope, bedsheet, or other fabric/material can be looped or tied to create sustainable point of attachment that may result in self-harm or loss of life). This was added in the 2022 version.

diagrams.title: Emergency, Multiple Patient Exam / Treatment
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where multiple exam or treatment areas are to be in one space, each exam or treatment area is required to contain a minimum of 80 sf of clear floor space. The space between adjacent patient beds must be at least 5'. The distance between the side of a patient bed and a wall or partition must be at least 4'. Each exam or treatment area must be provided with the following three care station features, an exam light, accommodations for written or electronic documentation and a space for a visitor's chair. The enclosing space must provide At least one handwashing station for every four patient care stations and for each fraction there of. The handwashing station must comply with sections 2.1-2.8.7.2 and 2.1-2.8.7.3. The handwashing stations must be located in a visible and unobstructed location and be evenly distributed. Storage for supplies must be provided and needs to be readily accessible to each exam or treatment space within the multi-patient room.

diagrams.title: Emergency, Single Patient Exam / Treatment
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure proper hygiene, adequate space and privacy is provided the code has standards for Single Patient Exam Rooms. To address hygiene a handwashing station with sufficient distance guards to prevent splashing on the patient during the exam must be provided. Section 2.1-2.8.7.3 of the hospital code is dedicated to handwashing station requirements. The size of the room must be large enough such that it can provide 120 sf of floor area with minimum clear room dimension of 10' in any direction. An exam table or chair with 3' of minimum clear floor space at both sides and at the foot of the table or chair is required. Exam rooms are also required to have a portable or fixed exam light, storage for supplies, accommodations for written or electronic documentation, and space or a visitor's chair. Visual and speech privacy per section 2.1-2.1.2 must be provided.

children.body: A facility with five or fewer persons receiving medical care shall be classified as Group R-3 or shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential provided an automatic sprinkler system is installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 or Section P2904 of the Florida Building Code, Residential.
children.displayTitle: 308.4.2 Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Medical Care
children.titleText: Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Medical Care

children.body:
Institutional Group I-3 occupancy shall include buildings and structures that are inhabited by more than five persons who are under restraint or security. A Group I-3 facility is occupied by persons who are generally incapable of self-preservation due to security measures not under the occupants' control. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Correctional centers
  • Detention centers
  • Jails
  • Prerelease centers
  • Prisons
  • Reformatories
Buildings of Group I-3 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Sections 308.5.1 through 308.5.5 (see Section 408).

diagrams.title: Guardrail Openings - Exceptions 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 3
At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.
Section 1015.4 Exception 4
In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.

diagrams.title: Detention & Correctional Facilities - Common Use Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Only those common use areas serving accessible cells must be accessible. Elements provided in accessible common use areas must comply.
  • Dining/work surfaces (i.e., fixed tables and desks)
  • Drinking fountains (dual access, i.e., from standing/seated)

diagrams.title: Ships Ladders in Group I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In group I-3 facilities, a ship ladder may be used as part of the means of egress from control rooms or elevated observation stations when the following two conditions are met:
  • The control room or observation station must be not more than 250 sf.
  • The occupant load of the control room or observation station must not exceed 3.
A ships ladder may also be used to access unoccupied roofs in group I-3 facilities.

children.body: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed from sleeping areas, and other spaces where access or occupancy is permitted, to the exterior via means of egress without restraint. A Condition 1 facility is permitted to be constructed as Group R.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed from sleeping areas and any other occupied smoke compartment to one or more other smoke compartments. Egress to the exterior is impeded by locked exits.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is allowed within individual smoke compartments, such as within a residential unit comprised of individual sleeping units and group activity spaces, where egress is impeded by remote-controlled release of means of egress from such a smoke compartment to another smoke compartment.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is restricted from an occupied space. Remote-controlled release is provided to permit movement from sleeping units, activity spaces and other occupied areas within the smoke compartment to other smoke compartments.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which free movement is restricted from an occupied space. Staff-controlled manual release is provided to permit movement from sleeping units, activity spaces and other occupied areas within the smoke compartment to other smoke compartments.

Institutional Group I-4 occupancy shall include buildings and structures occupied by more than five persons of any age who receive custodial care for fewer than 24 hours per day by persons other than parents or guardians, relatives by blood, marriage or adoption, and in a place other than the home of the person cared for. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Adult day care
  • Child day care

diagrams.title: Group I-4 Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1006.2.1 (2021 and 2024) outlines how the code considers the varying evacuation needs of different occupancies. It modifies the criteria for requiring two exits based on three factors: the occupancy group, the occupant load, and the common path of egress travel. For instance, an I-4 daycare occupancy has a low threshold, requiring more than 10 occupants for two exits, compared to a B office occupancy, which requires more than 49 occupants. This distinction acknowledges that occupants in a B office can evacuate quickly and independently, while daycare occupants may need assistance and more time, necessitating more accessible egress options.

diagrams.title: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Building Code and Existing Building Code sections regarding Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies are to ensure that the occupants of habitable rooms in educational facilities and institutions that provide custodial care such as day cares are capable of exiting any room within the facility. This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

children.displayTitle: 308.6 Institutional Group I-4, Day Care Facilities
children.titleText: Institutional Group I-4, Day Care Facilities

children.body: A child day care facility that provides care for more than five but not more than 100 children 21/2 years or less of age, where the rooms in which the children are cared for are located on a level of exit discharge serving such rooms and each of these child care rooms has an exit door directly to the exterior, shall be classified as Group E.

diagrams.title: Child Care as Group E
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Day cares are typically classified as Group I-4 occupancies. However, they may be classified as a Group E when the building serves a total occupant load of 6-100 persons, under the age of 2-1/2 years, and each room has an exit directly to the outside at the level of exit discharge.

children.body: Rooms and spaces within places of religious worship providing such care during religious functions shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.
children.displayTitle: 308.6.2 Within a Place of Religious Worship
children.titleText: Within a Place of Religious Worship

children.body: A facility having five or fewer persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as part of the primary occupancy.
children.displayTitle: 308.6.3 Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Care
children.titleText: Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Care

children.body: A facility such as the above within a dwelling unit and having five or fewer persons receiving custodial care shall be classified as a Group R-3 occupancy or shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential.
children.displayTitle: 308.6.4 Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Care in a Dwelling Unit
children.titleText: Five or Fewer Persons Receiving Care in a Dwelling Unit

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group M
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sprinkler requirements are determined by a number of different criteria and are dependent on divisions of the building into one or more fire areas. However, in some states, sprinkler requirements may be more restrictive at a local or fire district level. Check with local building and fire jurisdictions to see if local building and/or fire codes have more restrictive requirements, such as for those buildings located in a Wildfire Urban Interface area.

diagrams.title: Air Leakage Vestibule
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

diagrams.title: High Piled Storage (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
High-piled storage refers to storage methods where items are stacked above a certain height, typically more than 12 feet. This can include:
  • Solid-piled storage: Items stacked directly on top of each other.
  • Palletized storage: Use of pallets to stack and organize goods.
  • Rack storage: Systems involving shelving units or racks for organization at various heights.
  • Bin box and shelf storage: Smaller units or shelves that are installed at high levels for additional storage capacity.
These methods maximize vertical space in warehouses or storage facilities, often requiring specific safety and construction considerations.

diagrams.title: Plumbing Fixture Count: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The calculation shown is based on Section 2902 of the building code using the occupant load factors of Section 1004, assuming half of the occupants are male and half are female. Other states and local jurisdictions may allow other methods which may provide a reduced occupant load, such as certain uses in California such as public schools or state owned buildings (See CPC 422.1, Table 4-1 for example). In addition, other plumbing codes may supersede Chapter 29 and/or have different plumbing fixture ratios than those shown here.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Even though the restroom and corridor is not normally occupied area, the major use is Mercantile. Based on the definition of "gross area", the restroom and corridor area is included in occupant load calculation. The diagram shown is based on the 2018 codes which allows an Occupant Load Factor of 150 instead of 100 for business areas.

The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the room level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

diagrams.title: NFPA Mercantile Classifications
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mercantile Subclassifications - Mercantile occupancies are broken down into three subclassifications. Class A is the largest mercantile occupancy and are those occupancies that are greater than 30,000sq.ft or more than three stories tall. Class B mercantile occupancies are 3,000 sq.ft. to 30,000 sq.ft. and a maximum height of three stories, or a maximum of 3,000 sq.ft. and two to three stories high. Class C mercantile occupancies are the smallest. They occupy a maximum of 3,000 sq.ft. and only one story. Fire protection and detection features, number and means of egress, and emergency lighting requirements vary based on the subclassification of the mercantile occupancy.

diagrams.title: Retail Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: ADA Advisory 203.9 Employee Work Areas. Although areas used exclusively by employees for work are not required to be fully accessible, consider designing such areas to include non-required turning spaces, and provide accessible elements whenever possible. Under the ADA, employees with disabilities are entitled to reasonable accommodations in the workplace; accommodations can include alterations to spaces within the facility. Designing employee work areas to be more accessible at the outset will avoid more costly retrofits when current employees become temporarily or permanently disabled, or when new employees with disabilities are hired. Contact the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) at www.eeoc.gov for information about title I of the ADA prohibiting discrimination against people with disabilities in the workplace.

diagrams.title: Fitting Rooms (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: ADA Advisory 803.1 General. Partitions and doors should be designed to ensure people using accessible dressing and fitting rooms privacy equivalent to that afforded other users of the facility. Section 903.5 requires dressing room bench seats to be installed so that they are at the same height as a typical wheelchair seat, 17 inches to 19 inches. However, wheelchair seats can be lower than dressing room benches for people of short stature or children using wheelchairs. If construction must comply with A117.1-2017, ensure the proper turn space is used for new or existing construction, as applicable.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calculation: Retail (LSC vs BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The occupant load factor (OLF) in the Life Saftey Code is determined by table 7.3.1.2 and is dependent on how the space will be utilized. Table 7.3.1.2 differs from the building codes table 1004.1 and can result in a significantly different occupant load than required for the building code. For mall structures the occupant load for the entire Mall is determined by Figure 7.3.1.2(a) and Figure 7.3.1.2(b) and is based on the size of the mall.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Occupancy Classification and Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental use areas on any given level of a building may not occupy more than 10% of the building area of that level. Incidental use areas take on the occupancy classification of the occupancy which the incidental use area is located within.

children.body:
Mercantile Group M occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure or a portion thereof for the display and sale of merchandise, and involves stocks of goods, wares or merchandise incidental to such purposes and accessible to the public. Mercantile occupancies shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Department stores
  • Drug stores
  • Markets
  • Motor fuel-dispensing facilities
  • Retail or wholesale stores
  • Sales rooms

The aggregate quantity of nonflammable solid and nonflammable or noncombustible liquid hazardous materials stored or displayed in a single control area of a Group M occupancy shall not exceed the quantities in Table 414.2.5(1).

diagrams.title: Hazmat in Group M
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This section applies specifically to mercantile occupancies that are selling nonflammable and noncombustible liquid hazardous materials. This code section refers the user to Table 414.2.5(1). This table outlines the MAQ (maximum allowable quantities) of materials, based on type and class, that are permitted within a single control area. The quantities of these materials can be increased by 100% if the building is sprinklered, or if the materials are stored in an approved cabinet. The quantities can be increased by 200% if the materials are stored in an approved cabinet and the building is sprinklered.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Dwelling and Sleeping Units
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Structure-Borne Sound
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structure borne sound is sound transferred through the assembly by the impact or vibration of the actual phyisical materials. Some methods to reduce this sound transmission includes sound reducing mats between the flooring and the substrate on top of the floor. Also, the use of resilient light gauge metal channels on the bottom of joists can also help reduce transmission of structure borne sound.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Bathroom Exemption (NFPA 13)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Bathrooms in residential occupancies that are less than 55 sq.ft. and have walls and ceilings of noncombustible or limited-combustible materials are not required to have sprinkler protection.

diagrams.title: Sprinkler Exemption: Closets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sprinklers may be omitted within hotel and motel sleeping units and residential dwelling units inside of clothing and pantry closets that do not exceed 24 sf and have walls and ceilings of noncombustible or limited-combustible materials, such as gypsum wallboard.

diagrams.title: Egress Through Intervening Spaces: #4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where it is necessary to access an exit through another space, certain provision must be in place for this to be allowed. Otherwise, access through an intervening space to an exit is prohibited. This section outlines those areas where accessing through a space to an exit is permissible.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Sprinkler System Installation Standards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: There are three standards referenced for the installation of fire sprinkler systems. NFPA 13, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems, can be used for the installation of all fire sprinkler systems. However, certain portions of the code permit the fire sprinkler system to be installed per either NFPA 13R or NFPA 13D. NFPA 13R, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in Low-Rise Residential Occupancies, can be used for Group R occupancies that are four stories or less, and no higher than 60 feet, above grade plane. NFPA 13D, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in One- and Two- Family Dwellings and Manufactured Homes, can be used from 1 and 2 family dwellings, townhouses, and Group R-3 and Group R-4, Condition 1 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Live Work Unit Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Live/work units regulated under 2021-based building code Section 508.5 present a highly adaptable occupancy model, particularly well-suited to dense urban environments and multifamily developments. However, this hybrid typology comes with precise constraints that significantly influence spatial planning.

Means of egress and accessibility requrements apply based on the function of each space. Occupant loads must be calculated and documented separately for the living and working portions. Plumbing fixture count calculations also require careful attention, particularly in jurisdictions with stricter interpretations of how shared facilities may be used. If a tenant brings in external workers or clients—even occasionally—it may shift the classification of the work zone in ways that trigger more demanding requirements for fixtures, structural design, or fire protection. Uses such as light fabrication, artist studios, or boutique production can blur the line between permitted commercial activities and those prohibited under Group H or S occupancies, such as those involving hazardous materials or heavy storage. It is essential to engage the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) early to determine how they define and enforce these distinctions in mixed-use contexts.

Egress requirements must be carefully considered before simply choosing something like a spiral stair or residential style stairway. Ventilation requirements under the Mechanical Code must be applied according to the function of each space, which could complicate HVAC zoning and system layouts. Similarly, fire alarm and sprinkler designs must account for both residential and commercial activities within a single unit envelope. These complexities demand a multidisciplinary approach to design coordination—where architecture, mechanical systems, code compliance, and occupancy planning are considered together from the earliest project stages.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Design Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupant loads are determined by the function of the space, not by the occupancy group. Some occupant loads are determined based on gross area, and others are based on net areas, which allows a deduction for certain spaces not usually occupied, such as restrooms serving assembly areas. In this example, the restrooms serving the unconcentrated assembly areas are excluded from the areas for determining occupant loads.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Riser Height and Tread Depth
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In 2024 code editions, Section 1011.5.2 is further clarified for 1011.5.2, Exception 3 that within R-2 dwelling units not required by Chapter 11 to be Accessible or Type A dwelling or sleeping units can have riser dimensions typically found in R-3 occupancy groups.

children.body: Residential Group R includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for sleeping purposes when not classified as an Institutional Group I or when not regulated by the Florida Building Code, Residential.

The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:
BOARDING HOUSE.
CONGREGATE LIVING FACILITIES.
DORMITORY.
GROUP HOME.
GUEST ROOM.
LODGING HOUSE.
PERSONAL CARE SERVICE.
TRANSIENT.

Residential Group R-1 occupancies containing sleeping units where the occupants are primarily transient in nature, including:
  • Boarding houses (transient) with more than 10 occupants
  • Congregate living facilities (transient) with more than 10 occupants
  • Hotels (transient)
  • Motels (transient)

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

diagrams.title: Exit Signs in R-1 Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In larger R-1 occupancies, both high and low exit signs are required. In a condition where a corridor has smoke, the smoke rises to the ceiling and can be so dark and thick that exit signs are obscured, and it could be hazardous to evacuate in a standing position. So that people can see exit signs obscured by smoke, the lower ones are provided.

diagrams.title: GFCI locations - Other than Dwellings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A GFCI outlet, or Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter outlet, is a type of electrical outlet designed to protect people from electric shock. This is achieved by comparing the incoming and outgoing currents. If there is an imbalance, the GFCI outlet quickly interrupts the power to prevent injury.

diagrams.title: Low-Level Exit Signs, Group R-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Low level exit signs play a critical role in building safety and egress (exit) strategies, particularly in emergency situations. In cases of fire, smoke tends to rise creating a layer of visibility at lower levels. Low-level exit signs remain visible in these conditions, guiding building occupants, who may need to resort to crawling, towards the safest exit path even in dense smoke.
For individuals who navigate from a lower eye level, such as those in wheelchairs, low-level signs can offer a clearer, more direct line of sight.
Overall, having low-level exit signs in addition to traditional exit signs enhances the safety redundancy, making sure an indicator is visible for all occupants. These benefits make low-level exit signs an instrumental part of creating a comprehensive and accessible egress strategy. Ensuring these signs meet the building code requirements, such as requirements for illumination, placement, and characteristics, increases their effectiveness and optimizes them for the purpose they serve.

diagrams.title: Lighting Outlets - Guest Rooms / Suites
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The electrical code provides specific requirements, and exceptions, for guest rooms, which are generally Group R-1 occupancy, for transient individuals.

children.body:
Residential Group R-2 occupancies containing sleeping units or more than two dwelling units where the occupants are primarily permanent in nature, including:
  • Apartment houses
  • Boarding houses (nontransient)
  • Congregate living facilities (nontransient) with more than 16 occupants
  • Convents
  • Dormitories
  • Fraternities and sororities
  • Hotels (nontransient)
  • Live/work units
  • Monasteries
  • Motels (nontransient)
  • Vacation timeshare properties

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

diagrams.title: Attic Fire Protection - Condition 1 & 2 (NFPA 13R)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Attic protection shall be provided as follows:
  1. Attics that are used or intended for living purposes or storage shall be protected by an automatic sprinkler system.
  2. Where fuel-fired equipment is installed in an unsprinklered attic, not fewer than one quick-response intermediate temperature sprinkler shall be installed above the equipment.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Excpt. 1-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. There are several situations in which exceptions are permitted:
  • Handrails within dwelling units are permitted to be interrupted by a newel post at a turn or landing.
  • Within a dwelling unit, the use of a volute, turnout, starting easing or starting newel is allowed over the lowest tread.
  • Handrail brackets or balusters attached to the bottom surface of the handrail that do not project horizontally beyond the sides of the handrail within 1-1/2 inches of the bottom of the handrail shall not be considered obstructions. For each 1/2 inch of additional handrail perimeter dimension above 4 inches, the vertical clearance dimension of 1-1/2 inches shall be permitted to be reduced by 1/8 inch.

diagrams.title: Window Opening Control Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window Opening Control Devices are safety devices installed on windows to limit the opening size, helping to prevent accidental falls, particularly for children. These devices are designed to restrict the window opening to a maximum of 4 inches, while still allowing for easy operation of the window for egress purposes if needed.

Window Opening Control Devices must comply with the ASTM F2090 standard, ensuring their quality and effectiveness in preventing accidents related to window falls. They should be operational from inside the room without the use of keys or tools. In emergency situations, these devices can be released to allow the window to fully open without compromising the minimum net clear opening area required for emergency escape and rescue openings.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Exist. Apartments (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: There are four fire options for existing apartment buildings. Based on the option in place, the fire protection, egress, and construction requirements will vary. Option 1 is for existing apartment buildings with no fire protection equipment. Option 2 is for buildings that are provided with a complete automatic detection system only. This option must also meet the installation requirements of section 31.3.4.4. Option 3 is for buildings equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in select areas. Section 31.3.5.9 outlines the areas where sprinklers are required in order to meet Option 3 allowances. Option 4 is for buildings equipped throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system.

diagrams.title: Arrangement of Means of Egress: Apartments (NFPA)
Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Guards At Stairs (Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Housing: ADA & Title II Entities
diagrams.descriptionHtml: ADA Title II refers to the regulations set out in 28 CFR 35.151 and the 2004 ADAAG at 36 CFR part 1191, appendices B and D, which are part of the 2010 Standards for State and local government facilities. These standards establish minimum requirements for accessibility and usability by individuals with disabilities during the design, construction, additions, and alteration of State and local government facilities. Compliance for new construction projects and alterations that began on or after March 15, 2012, must follow the 2010 Standards. Before that date, the 1991 Standards (without the elevator exemption), the UFAS, or the 2010 Standards may be used for such projects when the start of construction commences on or after September 15, 2010.

diagrams.title: Housing: Regulations for Title III Entities
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Housing, whether provided by public or private entities, must comply with the ADA Title III requirements for new construction and alterations, as well as the specific requirements outlined in sections 233 and 809 for residential dwelling units. The specific requirements depend on whether the housing is provided by entities subject to HUD Section 504 regulations or not. Housing provided by public entities for sale to individual owners must also meet these requirements. Housing at a place of education must comply with the provisions of the 2010 Standards applicable to transient lodging, with exceptions outlined in section 224.1 for certain types of residential structures, and section 28 CFR 35.151 (f) for kitchens and multi-bedroom units.

diagrams.title: Housing: ADA Regulations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Public housing refers to residential dwelling units that are designed, constructed, altered, or offered for sale to individuals by public entities or programs operated by public entities, as well as residential dwelling units in facilities provided by entities subject or not subject to HUD Section 504 regulations. These residential dwelling units must comply with the accessibility standards for residential facilities in the 2010 ADA Standards, including sections 233 and 809. Housing at a place of education leased on a year-round basis exclusively to graduate students or faculty and does not contain any public or common use areas available for educational programming are not subject to the transient lodging standards and shall comply with the requirements for residential facilities in sections 233 and 809 of the 2010 Standards.

diagrams.title: Live Work Unit Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Live/work units regulated under 2021-based building code Section 508.5 present a highly adaptable occupancy model, particularly well-suited to dense urban environments and multifamily developments. However, this hybrid typology comes with precise constraints that significantly influence spatial planning.

Means of egress and accessibility requrements apply based on the function of each space. Occupant loads must be calculated and documented separately for the living and working portions. Plumbing fixture count calculations also require careful attention, particularly in jurisdictions with stricter interpretations of how shared facilities may be used. If a tenant brings in external workers or clients—even occasionally—it may shift the classification of the work zone in ways that trigger more demanding requirements for fixtures, structural design, or fire protection. Uses such as light fabrication, artist studios, or boutique production can blur the line between permitted commercial activities and those prohibited under Group H or S occupancies, such as those involving hazardous materials or heavy storage. It is essential to engage the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) early to determine how they define and enforce these distinctions in mixed-use contexts.

Egress requirements must be carefully considered before simply choosing something like a spiral stair or residential style stairway. Ventilation requirements under the Mechanical Code must be applied according to the function of each space, which could complicate HVAC zoning and system layouts. Similarly, fire alarm and sprinkler designs must account for both residential and commercial activities within a single unit envelope. These complexities demand a multidisciplinary approach to design coordination—where architecture, mechanical systems, code compliance, and occupancy planning are considered together from the earliest project stages.

diagrams.title: Riser Height and Tread Depth
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In 2024 code editions, Section 1011.5.2 is further clarified for 1011.5.2, Exception 3 that within R-2 dwelling units not required by Chapter 11 to be Accessible or Type A dwelling or sleeping units can have riser dimensions typically found in R-3 occupancy groups.

children.body:
Residential Group R-3 occupancies where the occupants are primarily permanent in nature and not classified as Group R-1, R-2, R-4 or I, including:
  • Buildings that do not contain more than two dwelling units
  • Boarding houses (nontransient) with 16 or fewer occupants
  • Boarding houses (transient) with 10 or fewer occupants
  • Care facilities that provide accommodations for five or fewer persons receiving care
  • Congregate living facilities (nontransient) with 16 or fewer occupants
  • Congregate living facilities (transient) with 10 or fewer occupants
  • Owner-occupied lodging houses with five or fewer guest rooms and 10 or fewer occupants

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 4
