diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Excpt. 1-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. There are several situations in which exceptions are permitted:
  • Handrails within dwelling units are permitted to be interrupted by a newel post at a turn or landing.
  • Within a dwelling unit, the use of a volute, turnout, starting easing or starting newel is allowed over the lowest tread.
  • Handrail brackets or balusters attached to the bottom surface of the handrail that do not project horizontally beyond the sides of the handrail within 1-1/2 inches of the bottom of the handrail shall not be considered obstructions. For each 1/2 inch of additional handrail perimeter dimension above 4 inches, the vertical clearance dimension of 1-1/2 inches shall be permitted to be reduced by 1/8 inch.

diagrams.title: Window Opening Control Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window Opening Control Devices are safety devices installed on windows to limit the opening size, helping to prevent accidental falls, particularly for children. These devices are designed to restrict the window opening to a maximum of 4 inches, while still allowing for easy operation of the window for egress purposes if needed.

Window Opening Control Devices must comply with the ASTM F2090 standard, ensuring their quality and effectiveness in preventing accidents related to window falls. They should be operational from inside the room without the use of keys or tools. In emergency situations, these devices can be released to allow the window to fully open without compromising the minimum net clear opening area required for emergency escape and rescue openings.

diagrams.title: Stair Riser / Tread Depth: R-3/R-2 Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1011.5.2, Exception 3: Stair treads at one and two family dwellings (Group R-3) and within Group R-2 units allow for a steeper slope (rise / run) than do stairs in common or public access areas. The requirements are a minimum stair tread length (horizontal component) and maximum stair rise (vertical component). Variations of treads from tread to tread or smaller tread lengths and higher riser heights increase the potential for tripping or falls on stairways. The 2024 version further clarifies that this exception is only allowed for R-2 units not required to be Accessible or Type A sleeping units.

diagrams.title: Guards At Stairs (Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

diagrams.title: Riser Height and Tread Depth
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In 2024 code editions, Section 1011.5.2 is further clarified for 1011.5.2, Exception 3 that within R-2 dwelling units not required by Chapter 11 to be Accessible or Type A dwelling or sleeping units can have riser dimensions typically found in R-3 occupancy groups.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Design Occupant Load
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupant loads are determined by the function of the space, not by the occupancy group. Some occupant loads are determined based on gross area, and others are based on net areas, which allows a deduction for certain spaces not usually occupied, such as restrooms serving assembly areas. In this example, the restrooms serving the unconcentrated assembly areas are excluded from the areas for determining occupant loads.

diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked
Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

children.body: Care facilities for five or fewer persons receiving care that are within a single-family dwelling are permitted to comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential provided an automatic sprinkler system is installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 or Section P2904 of the Florida Building Code, Residential.

Owner-occupied lodging houses with five or fewer guest rooms and 10 or fewer occupants shall be permitted to be constructed in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Residential, provided that an automatic sprinkler system is installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 or Section P2904 of the Florida Building Code, Residential.

Residential Group R-4 occupancy shall include buildings, structures or portions thereof for more than five but not more than 16 persons, excluding staff, who reside on a 24-hour basis in a supervised residential environment and receive custodial care. Buildings of Group R-4 shall be classified as one of the occupancy conditions specified in Section 310.6.1 or 310.6.2. This group shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Alcohol and drug centers
  • Assisted living facilities
  • Congregate care facilities
  • Group homes
  • Halfway houses
  • Residential board and custodial care facilities
  • Social rehabilitation facilities
Group R-4 occupancies shall meet the requirements for construction as defined for Group R-3, except as otherwise provided for in this code or shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Residential provided the building is protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.2.8.

diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked
Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

children.body: This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which all persons receiving custodial care, without any assistance, are capable of responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

This occupancy condition shall include buildings in which there are any persons receiving custodial care who require limited verbal or physical assistance while responding to an emergency situation to complete building evacuation.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

diagrams.title: Draft Curtains in ESFR Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where storage protected by an ESFR sprinkler system is located adjacent to an area protected by a standard-response sprinkler system the areas shall be separated by a 2 ft. tall draft curtain of noncombustible material. Centered beneath the draft curtain, a 4' wide clear aisle is required.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

diagrams.title: Exterior Envelope: Roof - Metal Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

children.body: Storage Group S occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for storage that is not classified as a hazardous occupancy.

diagrams.title: Guardrail Openings - Exceptions 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 3
At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.
Section 1015.4 Exception 4
In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.

diagrams.title: Egress Through Intervening Spaces: # 2 & 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where it is necessary to access an exit through another space, certain provision must be in place for this to be allowed. Otherwise, access through an intervening space to an exit is prohibited. This section outlines those areas where accessing through a space to an exit is permissible.

children.body: A room or space used for storage purposes that is accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as part of that occupancy.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occ.: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Accessory occupancies are part of the mixed occupancy provisions to allow small amounts of spaces that are used by other parts of the same space but not count against them in regards to allowable area calculations. They may be used in combination with separated and non-separated occupancy provisions. For example, an office in a retail establishment, or a small conference room in a large office space.

The two spaces on the left, because they support (and have some sort of spacial connection to the main space), are ancillary; therefore, they can be "Accessory occupancies". Tenant space #2 is separate, does not support the tenant #1 space, nor is it connected. Therefore, it is not ancillary and cannot likely be an accessory occupancy. If a space supports a main space, but is not directly connected, the design professional should make a determination if this is an appropriate accessory occupancy designation.

children.body:
Storage Group S-1 occupancies are buildings occupied for storage uses that are not classified as Group S-2, including, but not limited to, storage of the following:
  • Aerosol products, Levels 2 and 3
  • Aircraft hangar (storage and repair)
  • Bags: cloth, burlap and paper
  • Bamboos and rattan
  • Baskets
  • Belting: canvas and leather
  • Books and paper in rolls or packs
  • Boots and shoes
  • Buttons, including cloth covered, pearl or bone
  • Cardboard and cardboard boxes
  • Clothing, woolen wearing apparel
  • Cordage
  • Dry boat storage (indoor)
  • Furniture
  • Furs
  • Glues, mucilage, pastes and size
  • Grains
  • Horns and combs, other than celluloid
  • Leather
  • Linoleum
  • Lumber
  • Motor vehicle repair garages complying with the maximum allowable quantities of hazardous materials listed in Table 307.1(1) (see Section 406.8)
  • Photo engravings
  • Resilient flooring
  • Silks
  • Soaps
  • Sugar
  • Tires, bulk storage of
  • Tobacco, cigars, cigarettes and snuff
  • Upholstery and mattresses
  • Wax candles

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

children.body:
Storage Group S-2 occupancies include, among others, buildings used for the storage of noncombustible materials such as products on wood pallets or in paper cartons with or without single thickness divisions; or in paper wrappings. Such products are permitted to have a negligible amount of plastic trim, such as knobs, handles or film wrapping. Group S-2 storage uses shall include, but not be limited to, storage of the following:
  • Asbestos
  • Beverages up to and including 16-percent alcohol in metal, glass or ceramic containers
  • Cement in bags
  • Chalk and crayons
  • Dairy products in nonwaxed coated paper containers
  • Dry cell batteries
  • Electrical coils
  • Electrical motors
  • Empty cans
  • Food products
  • Foods in noncombustible containers
  • Fresh fruits and vegetables in nonplastic trays or containers
  • Frozen foods
  • Glass
  • Glass bottles, empty or filled with noncombustible liquids
  • Gypsum board
  • Inert pigments
  • Ivory
  • Meats
  • Metal cabinets
  • Metal desks with plastic tops and trim
  • Metal parts
  • Metals
  • Mirrors
  • Oil-filled and other types of distribution transformers
  • Parking garages, open or enclosed
  • Porcelain and pottery
  • Stoves
  • Talc and soapstones
  • Washers and dryers

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Group S-2 Enclosed Parking Garage With Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A Group S-2 enclosed parking garage with no more than one story above grade plane, located beneath a Group S-2 open parking garage, is considered a separate building for construction type purposes if the following conditions are met:
  • The sum of area actual area to allowable area ratios of both occupancies must not exceed 1;
  • The enclosed garage is of type I or II construction and has equal or greater fire resistance than required for the open parking garage;
  • The open garage complies with height and tier limits in Table 406.5.4;
  • The floor assembly separating the two types of garages must meet the enclosed garage's fire protection requirements;
  • Openings other than exit openings between the two garage types are not required to be protected;
  • And the enclosed garage must be used solely for private vehicle parking or storage.
An accessory use area up to 1000 sf that may contain an office, waiting room, and toilet room is allowed in the enclosed garage. The enclosed garage may also contain a mechanical room that serves the building.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

diagrams.title: Enclosures for Outdoor Electrical Installations (≥1000V)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To deter unqualified persons access to electrical equipment the code requires an enclosure around the equipment. The enclosure may be a 7' tall fence or a 6' tall fence with a 1 ft extension containing 3 rows of barbwire. Access to the enclosure must be via lockable gates. Where a fence, screen or other perforated barrier comprises the enclosure wall, the electrical equipment must be held away from the barrier by the distances in Table 110.31.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

children.displayTitle: Section 312 Utility and Miscellaneous Group U

children.body:
Buildings and structures of an accessory character and miscellaneous structures not classified in any specific occupancy shall be constructed, equipped and maintained to conform to the requirements of this code commensurate with the fire and life hazard incidental to their occupancy. Group U shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
  • Agricultural buildings
  • Aircraft hangars, accessory to a one- or two-family residence (see Section 412.5)
  • Barns
  • Carports
  • Communication equipment structures with a gross floor area of less than 1,500 square feet (139 m2).
  • Fences more than 6 feet (1829 mm) in height
  • Grain silos, accessory to a residential occupancy
  • Greenhouses Livestock shelters
  • Private garages
  • Retaining walls
  • Sheds
  • Stables
  • Tanks
  • Towers
